p: Do the magnitude of and mechanisms driving changes in precipitation variability depend on the timescale considered? Fig. 4 shows the change in variability of precipitation at temporal resolutions from 1 day to 3 years averaged over all land grid points for CMIP5 (Fig. S5 shows CESM1 and GFDL, extending to multi-decadal time periods; Fig. S6 shows the change in power spectral density). Changes in precipitation variability averaged over global ocean grid points are similar, with somewhat smaller magnitude; we primarily focus on land because this is where most impacts on humans will be felt, but we do not expect the dominant mechanisms for change to differ substantially over ocean.
